dataset.title: Intensive Stream Survey Geomorphology Data from 2010 to 2011 at the Coweeta Hydrologic Laboratory, Otto, NC

creator.organizationName: Coweeta Long Term Ecological Research Program

address.deliveryPoint: Daniel B. Warnell School of Forestry and Natural Resources

abstract.para: From June 2010 until February 2011, fifty streams were surveyed to determine the physical characteristics of streams in forested, traditional land use, and developed settings. Cross-sectional measurements were taken at 16 cross-sections on each reach. The distance between each cross-section was twice the average active channel width (which was determined prior to the survey). At one to three locations within each surveyed reach, slope was determined by placing a laser level at a location upstream and then measuring the amount of elevation change at the water surface. Between each cross-section, the instream habitat was recorded. Large woody debris was measured where it was found within the surveyed reach of the stream. Only LWD with diameter >10 cm was measured. At a representative riffle within the reach, a Wolman pebble count (100 randomly selected pieces of sediment) was taken.

keywordSet.keyword: Movement of Inorganic Matter, Disturbance Patterns

section.title: Wolman Pebble
section.para: At a representative riffle within the reach, a Wolman pebble count (100 randomly selected pieces of sediment) was taken. The b-axis of 100 randomly selected pieces of sediment were measured.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: CWT Study Site ULTRB -- Upper Little Tennessee River Basin, North Carolina, USA. The Upper Little Tennessee Watershed Basin is a primary focus for The Coweeta LTER's regional ecological and socio-ecological research.
CWT Study Site CWTBASIN -- Coweeta Basin, Macon County, North Carolina, USA. The overall boundary for the Coweeta Hydrologic laboratory.

section.title: Bed Sediment
section.para: At a representative riffle within each reach, a Wolman pebble count was conducted. The b-axis of 100 randomly selected pieces of sediment were measured.

Cross-sectional surveys of fifty streams spread out amongst three different land uses (forested, traditonal, developed) were conducted. At a representative riffle within each reach, a Wolman pebble count was conducted.
At a representative riffle within the reach, a Wolman pebble count (100 randomly selected pieces of sediment) was taken. The b-axis of 100 randomly selected pieces of sediment were measured.

section.title: Cross Sections
section.para: Cross-sectional measurements were taken at 16 cross-sections on each reach. Cross-sections were separated by two times the average channel width (determined prior to survey). The cross-sections were measured starting downstream and then moving upstream for each sequential cross-section. The first cross-section (0x) was located upstream of any influences from tributary confluences or bridge crossings.
Cross-sectional survey of fifty streams spread out amongst three different land uses (forested, traditonal, developed).

Cross-sections were separated by two times the average channel width (determined prior to survey). The cross-sections were measured starting downstream and then moving upstream for each sequential cross-section. The first cross-section (0x) was located upstream of any influences from tributary confluences or bridge crossings.

section.title: Gradient/Slope
section.para: Within each surveyed reach, one to three slope measurements were taken.
Cross-sectional survey of fifty streams spread out amongst three different land uses (forested, traditonal, developed). Within each surveyed reach, one to three slope measurements were taken.
Slope Measurement - A laser level was used to create a level line that was used to determine the height of the water surface below this line at three or more sites downstream of the laser level.

section.title: Habitat
section.para: Cross-sections were separated by two times the average channel width (determined prior to survey). The cross-sections were measured starting downstream and then moving upstream for each sequential cross-section. The instream habitat that occupied the area between the measured cross-sections was recorded as a percent of the area.
Cross-sectional surveys of fifty streams spread out amongst three different land uses (forested, traditional, developed) were conducted. Between each cross-section, the instream habitat was recorded.

Cross-sectional surveys of fifty streams spread out amongst three different land uses (forested, traditional, developed) were conducted. Between each cross-section, the instream habitat was recorded. Cross-sections were separated by two times the average channel width (determined prior to survey). The cross-sections were measured starting downstream and then moving upstream for each sequential cross-section. The instream habitat that occupied the area between the measured cross-sections was recorded as a percent of the area.

section.title: Large Wood Debris
section.para: Cross-sectional surveys of fifty streams spread out amongst three different land uses (forested, traditonal, developed) were conducted. Cross-sections were seperated by two times the average channel width (determined prior to survey). The cross-sections were measured starting downstream and then moving upstream for each sequential cross-section.

Cross-sectional surveys of fifty streams spread out amongst three different land uses (forested, traditonal, developed) were conducted. During the cross-section survey when LWD with diameter greater than 10 cm was found, measurements, location, and function were recorded.

Cross-sections were seperated by two times the average channel width (determined prior to survey). The cross-sections were measured starting downstream and then moving upstream for each sequential cross-section. LWD with diameter greater than 10 cm were measured.

abstract.para: Multi-scale process-oriented research is proposed on the consequences to the southernAppalachian socio-ecological system of the interaction between changing climate and landuse. Landscapes in the southeastern U.S. are expected to change profoundly in the next fivedecades as the socioeconomic factors driving the dramatic exurbanization of the past threedecades persist, and the changes to the rates, frequencies, and intensities of importantclimatic factors occur. Climate and land use change will especially impact the rural andquasi-rural lands that still characterize much of southern Appalachia where this research iscentered.The proposed research will extend long-term measurements, field experiments andinterdisciplinary modeling from small watershed studies to regional-scale analyses so as toaccount for increases in resource demand and competition from adjacent and more distantareas. The research focus will be on the provisioning service of water quantity, the regulatingservice of water quality, and the supporting service of maintaining biodiversity. Theoverarching question that guides this research is: How will key ecosystem processes and thefocal ecosystem services of water quantity, water quality, and biodiversity be impacted bythe: (1) transition in land uses from wildland to urban and peri-urban; (2) changes in climate;and (3) interactions between changes in land use and climate including both on-site and off-site feedbacks?

funding.para: This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under grant numbers DEB-0823293, DEB-9632854 and DEB-0218001. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Name of the Site and points on transect

textDomain.definition: Name of the Site and points on transect

attribute.attributeDefinition: Approximate UTM NAD83 Easting of cross-section
Approximate UTM NAD83 Northing of cross-section
Cross-sectional distance where water is flowing measured at each cross-section
Cross-sectional distance underlain by bed-sediment not colonized by vegetation, includes undercuts, measured at each cross-section
At each cross-section where a floodplain is present, cross-sectional distance connecting the floodplain bank top to the opposite bank, distance does not include undercuts
At each cross-section where a floodplain is not present, cross-sectional distance connecting the top of lowest bank to the opposite bank, distance does not include undercuts
Height of left bank above the water surface
Depth of water at base of left bank
Height of the left bank above the bed elevation of the thalweg ((left bank height - left bank water depth) + thalweg depth)
A measure of the distance (m) the stream is undercutting the left bank

Where present, the clearly recognizable relatively flat floodplain surface that is currently under construction was measured. The distance from the top of the bank to the edge of the floodplain was measured on river left (looking downstream)
A measure of the deepest portion of the stream along the cross-section
Location of the thalweg as a percent of the active channel width distance from the left bank
Height of right bank above the water surface
Depth of water at base of right bank
Height of the right bank above the bed elevation of the thalweg ((right bank height - right bank water depth) + thalweg depth). Bank height was measured from bed sediment up to the top of the bank
A measure of the distance (m) the stream is undercutting the right bank

Where present, the clearly recognizable relatively flat floodplain surface that is currently under construction was measured. The distance from the top of the bank to the edge of the floodplain was measured on river right (looking downstream)
The dominant particle size found along the cross-section.

At each cross section, the dominant habitat was determined. From least energy to most energy these habitats were: Pool/Pocket Water; Run/glide; Riffle; Rapid; Cascade; Step. The categories of habitats used were boulder cascade, boulder step, cascade, glide, log, mimi step, plunge pool, pocket water, pool, rapid, riffle, run, step, and tail.

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). attribute.attributeDefinition: Name of the site and points on transect

textDomain.definition: Name of the site and points on transect

attribute.attributeDefinition: Habitat classified as pool is relatively deep and slow moving
Habitat classified as run is relatively shallow (deeper than riffle but shallower than glide)
Habitat classified as riffle is shallow and fast moving but only produces infrequent white-water
Habitat classified as rapid is shallow and fast enough to have breaking waves on the surface of the water which creates the white-water associated with this habitat
Habitat classified as pocket water is located along the bank or behind an obstruction that creates a pocket of slow moving water
Habitat classified as cascade has hydraulic drops (waterfall)
Habitat classified as step has a hydraulic drop created by a step which can be created by large wood or boulders
The type of material that created the step (boulder, wood, etc.)

textDomain.definition: The type of material that created the step (boulder, wood, etc.)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Habitat that didn't fall into the other categories
